WRITING.TEXT:
"Cryptsetup open" takes me to my partition scheme, viewable by lsblk after my passphrase is given. I still need to finish installing the bootloader, but it should be easy enough. I just needed a break away from it to realize how easy it was.
ETA: Downvoters can kiss my ass. Leaving this up for any other newbies who might benefit.

WRITING.TITLE: No bootloader found, missing something obvious.
WRITING.TEXT:
Running UEFI, simple LUKS partition. All went fine.
Used:
bootcl insall
Got this famous message upon startup:
No loader found. Configuration files in \loader\entries\*.conf are needed.
Now how do I get back in and edit that? CTRL+ALT+F2 or any variation doesn't get me to the command line from that screen.
It's not possible to get there from the live USB, is it? Because when I run lblsk from there it doesn't even show that my disk is partitioned like it was before the installation guide in the wiki told me to reboot. Can I chroot into the system I've set up somehow?
Bit sleep deprived and been at this for hours. Just wanted to ask before I tried again tomorrow. If need be I'll keep running through this Arch install until I get it right, since I feel this was a good first attempt. Minus the fact that it won't start or anything.

I'm trying to upgrade with Aptitude, but it won't do it past version 1.2.3:
Unpacking python-oauth2client (1.2-3) ... Setting up python-oauth2client (1.2-3) ...
The following:
pip install --upgrade oauth2client
Gives me this:
OSError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/oauth2client-1.4.12-py2.7.egg'
I've downloaded the OAuthClient2 version I need (1.5.0), but I'm still unsure on how to use that to fix this version conflict. The ReadMe file for that directory is what gave me the last command I tried (pip install).

Would I need to replace Synaptic with Aptitude as my package handler? I'm on Crunchbang Plus Plus and using Synaptic by default currently.
EDIT: A lot of internet people are saying Aptitude is the better choice anyway. Here goes.

WRITING.TITLE: OAuth 2.0 conflict when trying to authorize Google Calendar for Conky.
WRITING.TEXT:
Following this guide to embed Google Calendar in Conky on my laptop running Debian:
http://xmodulo.com/integrate-google-calendar-linux-desktop.html
I got to this:
sudo python setup.py install
And got this:
Installed /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/gcalcli-3.4.0-py2.7.egg Processing dependencies for gcalcli==3.4.0 error: Installed distribution oauth2client 1.4.12 conflicts with requirement oauth2client=1.5.0,4.0.0
How can I update my OAuth 2.0 client to stop conflicting? Specifically to the version needed?
EDIT: Tried this:
sudo pip install --upgrade oauth2client
Successfully installed. Still get the same error when going back to the original command I'm trying to get past.

Obama is gay and Michelle is a tranny
Finally someone who can see past the lies of the media in our nation.

"Ha, ha, ha! And I did all this with a wooden gun!" he bragged while leaving.
Bender from Futurama.
Well, they're pissing me off because these assholes keep asking for ridiculously low prices. I guess I'll have to sell the hardware online.

WRITING.TITLE: Is it better to sell a whole PC you've built - or take it apart and sell the hardware.
WRITING.TEXT:
I have one I built last year for ~$750 total, and it's been difficult to sell for anything above $300. Would I make more money selling the hardware separately.
List:
* **Monitor** - Acer 21.5 inch HD * **Tower** - Cooler Master N200 * **Keyboard/Mouse** - Logitech MK120 Wired * **Motherboard** - MSI H81M-P33 Micro ATX; SATA 6Gb/s, USB 3.0 * **Graphics** - Gigabyte R9 270X * **PSU** - Corsair CX500 * **HDD** - Hitachi HUA721010KLA330 1 TB * **CPU** - Intel Core i3 Dual-Core * **RAM** - Crucial Ballistix Sports; 8 GB
